On Sun, Aug 19, 2012 at 9:10 AM, Benjamin Carlyle <
benjamincarlyle@...> wrote:

>
>
> Gentlefolk,
>
> I haven't posted here for a while, but many of you know me as having been
> active to varying degrees in the REST community for about 6 years now. I
> have some significant experience implementing REST in machine to machine
> environments (browser free environments) in backend business systems,
> realtime safety-related control systems, and a number of other esoteric
> environments that involve leading people and negotiating internal and
> business to business interfaces with people with varying levels of REST
> expertise and enthusiasm. Over the last few years I have been working with
> a number of others on the title mentioned in the subject line.
>
> It's a title I don't expect to pass by this list without criticism. It
> uses vocabulary that is often more on the SOA side than on the REST side.
> It focuses on REST "service contracts" (the set of urls exposed by a server
> and the server-specific meaning of standard methods and media types in
> those resources) as a standard tool for governing "REST services" as part
> of an overall service inventory. It focuses almost entirely on machine to
> machine interaction within the context of IT assets of a single enterprise.
> It doesn't deal much with browsers or mashups and it even spends a
> significant amount of time addressing issues like transactions and pub/sub.
> Perhaps for some the very fact that Thomas Erl's name is on the cover well
> push some buttons :)
>
> Nevertheless we collectively and I in particular have worked hard not to
> compromise on REST principles and constraints while still making the
> content accessible to SOA people and the general population. Within this
> context of heavy machine to machine interaction we deal with defining a
> uniform interface to cover an inventory of services within a particular
> enterprise, and how that should relate to service contracts and to broader
> standardisation efforts. We look to move past SOA's traditional limit of
> increasing intrinsic interoperability only within a given inventory and
> instead look for standard methods and media types to increase
> interoperability to more massive scales.
>
> We have sought to keep hypermedia core to the practice of building
> inventories of services and their related customers and to minimise
> coupling while also being explicit about why we do this. We have sought to
> drive a hard line on the stateless constraint and what that means to the
> aforementioned patterns of transactions (promoting compensating over
> atomic) and pub/sub (promoting cached polling and delta encoding).
>
> Some of you have already seen the material in various stages of completion
> as have many SOA guys. Over the last six months or so the manuscript
> changed significantly as we worked that feedback into the finished product.
>
> No book is perfect, but I hope this one will end up bringing the REST and
> SOA worlds together in a closer understanding without compromising one iota
> of what is important to each. I'm confident that despite the unfamiliar
> wording, context and audience that the book is written to be applied to
> that at its heart is a true application of REST constraints and to every
> possible extent a true application of the years of experience the REST
> community has developed.
>
> The book is available in ebook and hard cover:
> Amazon - http://amzn.com/0137012519
> Barnes and Noble -
> http://search.barnesandnoble.com/SOA-with-REST/Thomas-Erl/e/9780137012510(seriously? No permalink?)
> Home - http://servicetechbooks.com/rest
>
> Comments, discussion and criticism (timidly) welcome. I can't think of a
> better place to discuss the end result than this list.
>
>
>
